subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: Colonialism was the period when African countries were ruled by foreign European powers.
points: Foreign governments controlled land, people, and resources.
It began in the late 19th century during the 'Scramble for Africa'.

subsections.title: Major Colonial Powers
subsections.content: European countries that established colonies across Africa.
points: Britain, France, Portugal, Germany, Belgium, and Italy.
Each power imposed its language, laws, and systems.

subsections.title: Effects of Colonialism
subsections.content: Colonialism had long-lasting impacts on African societies.
points: Loss of independence and cultural identity.
Exploitation of African resources and labor.
Introduction of Western education, religion, and infrastructure.

subsections.title: African Resistance
subsections.content: Africans resisted colonial rule in various ways.
points: Armed uprisings (e.g. Maji Maji Rebellion in Tanzania).
Political movements and traditional leadership opposition.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: The transatlantic slave trade involved the capture and transportation of Africans to work in the Americas.
points: Began in the 15th century and lasted for over 400 years.
Involved European traders and African middlemen.

subsections.title: Impact on Africa
subsections.content: The slave trade severely affected African societies.
points: Millions of Africans were forcibly taken from their homes.
Communities were depopulated and weakened.
Cultural heritage and social structures were disrupted.

subsections.title: Abolition of the Slave Trade
subsections.content: Efforts to end the slave trade began in the 18th century.
points: Led by abolitionists in Europe and America.
Britain banned slave trade in 1807; slavery abolished in British colonies in 1833.

subsections.title: Background
subsections.content: Malawi, formerly Nyasaland, was under British colonial rule.
points: Part of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland (1953–1963).

subsections.title: Independence Movement
subsections.content: Malawians organized themselves to fight for self-rule.
points: Malawi Congress Party (MCP) was formed to demand independence.
Protests, petitions, and political organization increased pressure on colonial authorities.

subsections.title: Key Leader
subsections.content: Dr. Hastings Kamuzu Banda was the central figure in Malawi’s fight for independence.
points: Returned from abroad in 1958 to lead the movement.
Later became Malawi's first Prime Minister and President.

subsections.title: Independence Achievement
points: The country transitioned to self-governance.
Celebrated annually as Malawi’s Independence Day.
